item.title: Daily AOD and PM2.5 (2018)
item.description: Introduction Aerosol information, particularly PM2.5 concentration and aerosol optical depth (AOD), is essential for inquiries pertaining to air quality, human health impacts, and climate change. Previous approaches to estimate PM2.5 concentration from remote sensing data have largely relied on AOD retrieval techniques. However, the complexity of the AOD–PM2.5 interplay and limitations of existing algorithms pose significant challenges to achieving precise co-estimations of the two quantities at the same location. item.title: FY-4A AGRI AOD (2018)
item.description: Introduction The dataset is a colltection of FY-4A REGC AGRI AOD retrieved with transfer learning method (see details in the paper:A deep-learning and transfer-learning hybrid aerosol retrieval algorithm for FY4-AGRI: Development and verification over Asia). The AGRI AOD is built with 5min/4km. The dataset in this category is provided in 1 hour. Due to the cloud mask before March 12th being derived from a simplified empirical algorithm, there is a difference in data quality between the AOD data before and after March 12th.

item.title: High-resolution solar photovoltaic resource map
item.description: First estimation of high-resolution solar photovoltaic resource maps over China with Fengyun-4A satellite and machine learning Abstract Fengyun-4A (FY-4A), which is the latest-generation Chinese geostationary meteorological satellite, measures solar reflection and thermal emission with high temporal, spatial, and spectral resolutions. It is expected to be highly beneficial for solar resource assessment and forecasting in China. This study is the first to estimate, using FY-4A and a random forest model, the global horizontal irradiance (GHI) at a 4-km–15-min spatio-temporal resolution over China, as a means to arrive at a solar photovoltaic (PV) resource map.

item.title: Member 3
item.description: I was born in August 1992 and currently hold the position of Associate Researcher at the Institute of Atmospheric Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. My research focuses on satellite remote sensing of atmospheric aerosols and their climatic and environmental impacts. Here are some highlights of my work: Pioneered an early method for quantitatively retrieving nighttime aerosols based on city light. Developed a statistical learning-based aerosol interpolation method. Established an aerosol retrieval algorithm based on transfer learning.

This combination allows you to interact with the Julia language using IPython’s powerful graphical notebook, which combines code, formatted text, math, and multimedia in a single document. PACE group The Precipitation, Aerosol, Cloud, and Energy (PACE) group is a research team that focuses on studying the interactions and relationships between precipitation, aerosols, clouds, and energy in the Earth’s atmosphere. This interdisciplinary group typically includes atmospheric scientists, meteorologists, climatologists, and other researchers who collaborate to enhance our understanding of the complex processes occurring within the atmosphere. The primary areas of interest for the PACE group may include investigating the impact of aerosols on cloud formation, studying the role of clouds in the Earth’s energy balance, and exploring the dynamics of precipitation systems.

The research includes: The research conducted by the PACE group typically focuses on understanding the intricate relationships and interactions among precipitation, aerosols, clouds, and energy in the Earth’s atmosphere. Here are some key areas of research within the PACE group: Cloud-Aerosol Interactions: Investigating how aerosols (including natural and anthropogenic particles) influence cloud formation and properties. Studying the impact of aerosols on cloud microphysics, such as droplet size distribution and cloud lifetime.
